to make this a little bit simple so it fits your work potentially as well but yeah the way problem briefs work at
Nessa is the following essentially it includes a factual explanation of the problem um that's a really important
part it means that you have no gatekeeping language as much as you can obviously a lot of that is uh you know
scientific but yet you try to have no gatekeeping language you make sure that
everyone who reads the problem bre has at least a basic understanding of what you're trying to solve if it includes
any specific uh words or scientific data that you need to understand you give resources so people can understand what
the problem actually is and it's inclusive language because uh problem briefs are sent out to many many people
sometimes across uh across countries it tries to keep the content
to goals and does not suggest Solutions preemptively this is super important I use this every day with my teams
nowadays and I think uh it has made my work so much better it means that if you don't suggest Solutions preemptively
then people can be more creative in how they help you problem solve and reach the goals that you're trying to achieve with a feature or with whatever you're
trying to do uh it also helps people challenge your solution later down the
track which makes your solution better Your solution is likely not the not the best one more brains and more people
working on one solution is usually the better uh approach um it also includes

NASA problem briefs are not like you know a million pages of things it's like three or four and you try to keep it
